Also childhood illnesses, easily treated by relatively inexpensive medicines, meant he spent a huge part of his childhood unwell as his father could not afford treatment. When asked what it was like to take his first steps into a classroom, he replied: “It was incredibly exciting, and now it is even more exciting as there is a good chance I will go to secondary school.”Ali, nine, a Syrian refugee family from Deir ez-Zur district in eastern Syria arrived in Lebanon in 2011. They fled their home with several neighbours by bus toward a safer haven in Lebanon at the outbreak of civil war, which tore through their country. Heavy shelling bombarded their bus and the remainder of their journey had to be made on foot. Nine-year old Ali Ahmed’s father, an agricultural labourer explained that life in Lebanon was hard as they struggle to pay basic bills such as food and rent. As with most Syrian refugees, they are in debt to their landlords and to local shops owners. The collective family income is barely enough to cover any of their bills. Ali, one of the family’s 10 children, attends school 10km from home and dreams, one day, to be able to return home with his family to Syria.Chacha, 12, was born and raised in a small village in northwestern Tanzania, where he lives with his mother and two siblings. He has never set foot in a classroom and is one of a reported 1.89 million out-of-school children in the country today. Chacha works seven days per week scavenging gold mining sites, digging up rocks containing gold-residue. To avoid being captured or shot by mining and government police for trespass, he works under the cover of darkness, 6pm to 6am. The rocks he finds, he sells to middle men, for approximately £1.50 per shift, who crush them to extract the gold. He explained: “I have no choice, I know the work is dangerous but I feel I have to help provide for my family. It makes me sad not being able to go to school.” The money Chacha earns he uses to purchase clothes for himself and his siblings, the remainder he gives to his mother to contribute to food costs. When he returns home from his 12-hour shift, he tends to the family cattle.Owen, 16, has been enrolled in Buremba Primary School since 2007 and is one of eight siblings. Now in older years at school, he must pay more money. His parents are peasant farmers and work the land digging and picking tea, this means they must work most days to be able to keep up the payments. Buremba School is one of 60 new schools constructed under the Building Tomorrow and Educate A Child programme in Uganda.Afat, 12, left his home in Deir ez-Zor, Syria six years ago, forced out by the civil war which displaced millions of people, in his case to the Bekaa Valley, Lebanon. He is one of the thousands of Syrian refugee children sat in doorways of Lebanon’s many tents, shelters and makeshift homes dreaming of an education. Instead, he works 11 hours a day collecting scrap metal which he sells for around £2.50. He knows he has a right to education, but he is concerned to help provide for his family. He dreams of one day being able to return home to Syria with his family, to a better life.Mamoke, 10, has never been to school. Abandoned by her biological parents along with her eight siblings, she now lives with her grandmother in the village of Kuriyah. She grazes cattle six hours a day for her grandmother in return for her keep. She was registered for school but never enrolled. Her grandmother and  is unable to afford the voluntary parental contribution fees. Mamoke describes her household as poor, her grandmother unable to provide more than one meal per day for her. Mamoke added: “There are many days where we do not eat at all.” She dreams of becoming a teacher, if she was able to go to school, so she can help others in her current situation.Ikiriza, 5, Kamwenge District, Uganda. Ikiriza who is five years old lives in a small house with his nine brothers and sisters. His parents can’t afford school tuition fees for all the children, leaving Ikiriza with little choice but to fund his own education by working weekends carrying plastic jerry cans of water from the lake for various households of the neighbourhood in Kamwenge district. For this, he earns the equivalent of 5 US cents a day, which helps contribute towards his school fees at Bisozi Primary. He dreams of one day becoming a doctor so that he can help his father who suffers from ill health.Rami, six, lives at Beach Camp, on the sea front amongst the heart of the fishing community al-Shati in the northern Gaza Strip. Rami walks amongst the rubble of shelled buildings, a reminder of past and present conflicts. Restriction to employment and travel have meant many Palestinians are confined in Gaza. Some bright lights still shine as Rami attends grade P1 in school and dreams of becoming a footballer one day.Abdul 10, with his gaze to the floor, wrapped in blankets, huddles by the family stove. His father, Muhammad, emerges from the black of the adjoining room clutching an armful of medical documents written in French, a language he cannot read. His son is two years overdue a heart operation that would save his life. Srey, three, lives in a small dark room with her parents, siblings and relatives. A total of eight people live in a cramped, damp space in a makeshift barn of corrugated metal on the edge of the railroad tracks in the urban slums. The CYMCA Facility drop-in centre, funded in partnership between EAA and Aide et Action, provides emergency education to around 80 children in the area.Joender, six, from Maracaibo in Venezuela arrived in Ipiales, Colombia, after a 33-day journey mainly on foot. He is one of 3.5 million Venezuelan refugees that have left their homes following a catastrophic economic meltdown of his country leaving its citizens starving with no access to food, employment, medical services or education. He holds a packet of crackers, a kind donation from one of the many generous Colombians offering support to the Venezuelan people.Kennedy, 13, displaced to Uganda. He is another statistic of the 2.3 million South Sudanese refugees that fled the outbreak of civil war. Uganda alone shouldering 800,000 refugees. Kennedy was denied a normal childhood and instead became a witness to violence, torture and death in war. Not surprisingly, Kennedy’s family were unwilling to send him to school with threat of armed attack, abduction or recruitment by militias. On arrival in Uganda, Kennedy was still held back from attending school and fulfilling his dream of becoming a doctor. His parents were simply unable to afford the cost of a pair of shoes required for enrolment.“The canvas Billingham bags which carry the tools of my trade. They have sat beside me in the dust of countries around the world listening with me to every word of every story. I feel torn staring at them, joy at returning to my loved ones and the heartache of those I had to leave behind. Now they sit on the polished floor of my room, zipped up and lined up. I need them closer, to feel their weight on my shoulders again, I need to be away.….”As each year draws to a close, emotions you&nbsphave tried to control finally take grip. I feel torn – from the joy at returning to my&nbsploved ones and the heartache for those I&nbsphad to leave behind. I am staring at my canvas camera bags, which sat beside me in the dust of countries around the world.&nbspNow they sit on the polished floor of my room, zipped up. I need them closer, to feel their weight on my shoulders again, I need to be away…Here I have compiled a collection of photographs and memories, comprising the stories of some of the most marginalised children in the world.Winter: Abdul, a Syrian refugee aged 10, is seated in a makeshift shelter, perched high among&nbspthe rugged snowy mountain caps of Arsal, Lebanon. He holds his father’s hand as they both huddle&nbspby the stove for warmth. He has the haunting stare of a boy who knows he is&nbspgoing to die, an expression that cuts through the paraffin haze of the dark room as temperatures fall below zero. Mohammed, his father, gaunt from grief, explains&nbsphis son is two years overdue for an operation that could save his life.&nbspWith no means to finance it, he raises&nbsphis hands to the sky in hope that his prayers would be answered.&nbspI remember waiting to see my doctor as a child. I knew my turn would come Abdul knew his would not.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSpring:&nbspVenezuelan refugees who once ate together as families around their own tables&nbspnow eat from rubbish bins on their hands and knees to survive the crisis in their country. All the while, their president publicly feasts&nbspin lavish establishments. Roughly 3.5 million Venezuelans, among them doctors, lawyers and teachers, have left their country, out of starvation and fear.Joender, aged six, from Maracaibo in Venezuela, arrived in&nbspIpiales, Colombia, exhausted and hungry. He was offloaded with his family from a galvanised lorry like cattle, after a 33-day journey, mostly on foot, where they were forced to beg for food to survive. His cupped hands are&nbsprewarded with a packet of biscuits donated by a local in the town. He clutches&nbspthe packet like a prize. Having never begged for food myself as a child, I could not begin to understand the internal dialogue in doing so. I knew I could simply open a fridge door&nbspJoender&nbspcan’t.Summer:&nbspEsperence, aged 10, is a Haitian “restavek” or child slave. He was&nbspgiven away by his biological parents to a more affluent household and&nbspforced into a life of domestic servitude. The feeling of being abandoned proves&nbspto be too much for him. Standing in the kitchen and washing dishes, he simply shrugs his small shoulders, and one by one the tears roll&nbspdown his face. Hours each day are spent cleaning, sweeping and washing.&nbsp“I can never go out and play with my friends as my house family always call me back inside to do more jobs,”&nbsphe says.&nbspNearly 260 million children aren’t in school – do we care? Forced into a life of domestic servitude, Haiti’s child slavesThe global challenge to ensure all children can go to schoolThe importance of a solid work ethic was engrained into me at a young age. However, I remember the luxury of choice: I knew I could say no. Esperence knows he cannot.&nbspAutumn: Mamoke, aged 10, has never set foot in a classroom. Abandoned by her parents along with her siblings, she now lives with her grandmother at the mercy of abject poverty. In a dark room in remote north western Tanzania, she explains&nbsphow not going to school saddens&nbspher. But she nonetheless still dreams that somehow she could become a teacher to help others like her with no access to education. I didn't have a choice.&nbspI had to go to school. Mamoke didn’t have a choice, but that was because the right of education was unavailable to her. I realise I have taken so much&nbspfor granted in my life. Children around the world live with no access to healthcare, displaced from their home, going to sleep hungry, growing up in conflict and with no&nbspeducation.I did not choose my career any more than I chose my life. It chose me, and it is the greatest privilege, a blessing and a burden in the same breath. I&nbspwill continue to hold the world to account, hoping&nbspit will eventually force the changes that will create better choices for those who deserve them.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: labour mp calls colleagues c word
story: Leftwinger Lloyd Russell-Moyle accused other Labour MPs furious with the Opposition boss of acting out of ulterior motives.Instead of accepting any personal blame for Jeremy Corbyn or his failed manesto, the Brighton MP instead insisted Labour lost the election because the party and its MPs didn’t fight hard enough.Mr Russell-Moyle declared: “Fighting spirit is what we need. It’s what we lacked in the election”.The explosive remarks came in an exchange with a Labour colleague on Facebook messenger, which has been leaked to The Sun.Asked by the colleague why he wasn’t joining calls for Mr Corbyn to resign, Mr Russell-Moyle declared: “Because I’m not a c*** like those calling for his immediate resignation”.The firebrand MP added: “All the people saying stand down immediately are not saying it in good faith and that’s reason enough to ignore.“Anyonesays that they knew exactly what was wrong I’m afraid is a liar and a charlatan, and I will take no lessons from people who have spent the time undermining the party in all sorts of manners ofthe last few years”.In the conversation, Mr Russell-Moyle also stuck the kne into moderate Labour MP and potential leadership contender Jess Phillips, a long-standing Corbyn critic.Referring also to veteran Labour MP John Spellar, he added: “Jess Phillips would be a disaster. I think she would be truly terrible. I would have anyone but Jess. Well, maybe not anyone – Spellerwould be worse”.When contacted by The Sun last night about his attack on other Labour MPs and the use of his language, Mr Russell-Moyle said: “I said that because calling for Jeremy to go now is a silly and I would go so far to say c***ish thing to say.The best thing is for Jeremy Corbyn is to move aside in an orderly and organised fashion.“In private communications, it is an acceptable word to use, in public though it wouldn’t be.”He also accused the person who leaked the messages to be a suspended member of the party.Mr Russell-Moyle added: “People were speaking with knee jerk reactions the day after the election. We were hurting”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: labour hope munchkins momentum power
story: Let’s all sign up and vote for someone who’ll keep them out of power for the next decade or two.I say two quid. It’s moreyou’re working. But just tell them you’re unemployed or a student. They won’t check. Most of their current members are one or the other.And look who you have to choose from! Such a rich tapestry of political brilliance.David Lammy! Yay! The man who hates the police stop and search policy. A man who will brand you a racist before you’ve even opened your mouth.Richard Burgon! A plank of wood into which a village idiot has drilled two eyes and a mouth. Rebecca Long-Bailey — so inept even her own party members refer to her as Rebecca Wrong Daily.We could even co-ordinate and demand that they keep Magic Grandpa as boss. I mean, the party still seems to be in a state of denial. It was nothing to do with Corbyn! The voters loved him and loved our policies! We only didn’t win because of, er, Tory lies. The voters are thick, you see. Oh — and Brexit.For a very long time I was a member of the Labour Party. The main reason I left is the main reason nobody voted for it this time around. It is no longer the party of the poor and the working class.It has become a fringe group for metropolitan, middle-class liberals.Look at the only places it did well. Cambridge, Putney, Canterbury. Ha, bring on the revolution, then.“Are we manning the barricades, Cressida  Can I finish my Yakult first ”In a sense it doesn’t really matter who wins their leadership race. Labour lost not just because of the idiotic Corbyn or because of Brexit. It goes far deeper than that.It is the culture of the party. It despises everything its old voter base stands for. Even the moderates.It cannot abide patriotism, for a start. Its old voters are rather proud of Britain, and what Britain stands for. Corbyn and his allies hate our country.The traditional Labour voters believe in the traditional family, too. They have no time for identity politics and political correctness. They want a better deal, but don’t buy into all of the infantile agit-prop that goes along with today’s Labour Party.How the hell do you change that when the far-Left munchkins of Momentum still hold all the power There are still good people in the Labour Party. Some of them — like the brilliant Caroline Flint — lost their seats last week because of what Labour has become.Look at it now. Corbyn is STILL the leader. There is nothing they can do to get rid of him. He’s called for a period of reflection. It didn’t take the voters very long to reflect, did it We need a new party which represents working class people, especially away from London. That’s why I joined the Social Democratic Party.And we can happily leave the Labour Party to its “reflections”. Its support for terrorists, its loathing of the West. It STILL thinks it got its policies right.Even with a new leader it will still be terminally deluded.SO, is the BBC biased Welsh gob on a stick Huw Edwards thinks it is impeccably neutral. But then he would, wouldn’t he  But don’t take my word for it.Here’s the brilliant ex BBC journo and newsreader Michael Buerk, writing in the magazine The Critic. “ . . . all the presenters on the Today programme have been privately educated, like an astonishingly high proportion of the BBC’s editorial and production staff.”He added: “These are unormly bright, urban, young, well-educated arts graduates who have moved smoothly from one liberal institution to another. With little understanding of, or sympathy for, industry, business, the countryside or of course Brexiteers.”As Buerk pointed out, the BBC’s worldview is formed by the people who work for it.An estimated  per cent of them were against Brexit and there are plenty of objective studies which bear out a huge bias against Brexit.Go get ’em, BoJo.The advice is to always park where there are lots of people nearby .And in a well lit area. With the back of the car as close to a fence or kerb as possible.Anyway,someone sidles up to you in the pub and offers you a catalytic converter for a ton, here’s what to do.Kick him in the penkies and shove the converter as far up his rectum as is humanly possible.He’ll be passing incredibly clean wind, regardless of how many sprouts he eats.IS it possible to be more thick than Lauren Goodger  If so, how The Towie “star” got caught in a sting by the BBC. She was filmed endorsing a supposed health drink called Cyanora.She was told the product contained hydrogen cyanide, one of the most lethal substances known to mankind. But not known to Lauren, apparently.She was perfectly happy to give it her blessing. She admitted she’d never tried it . But then she also admitted she had never tried another product she had endorsed.Listen. Never believe TV personalities, actors, singers, etc.Don’t believe them when they tell you what way to vote. Don’t believe them when they’re trying to flog you something. For the most part they’re just greedy and thick as a plate of mince.OH what a pleasure it was to walk around a nice liberal, middle-class area of London last weekend singing: “Ohhhhhh Jeremy Corbyn!”The looks of hatred! I suppose it’s wrong to take pleasure in other people’s misery. But sometimes I can’t help it. Years of being told we’re all bigoted, racist and uneducated, I suppose.My we said she was more thrilled by the election result than she was by the birth of our daughter, which I think is pushing it a bit.Anyway, Boris Johnson has proven that he is a very canny politician indeed.He won the Mayor of London elections twice – by wooing the most right-on liberal electorate in Europe. And then he appealed to exactly the opposite tranche of voters to win the election last week.Huge credit, mind, to his adviser Dominic Cummings. A very sharp bloke – and from the North East. He never had any doubts about the result.What, being called a “smarty-pants”  If you end up troubled by having been called something like that  years previously, I would argue that your problems lie a lot deeper and were not actually caused by the insult.Shouldn’t we be trying to instil a degree of resilience among you people  Rather than feeling “triggered” at every single thing that’s said to them TURKEY is rapidly becoming the pariah state of the world.Its horrible government allows the genocidal terrorists Hamas to plot attacks on Israel from within Istanbul.The Turkish leader, Recep Erdogan, recently rolled out the red carpet for the Islamist maniacs of Hamas.A few years ago we were anxious to welcome Turkey into the European Union.Now we should impose sanctions on the country.Friends of anti-Jewish terrorists are no friends of ours.CHRISTMAS is the time of year when you open a bottle from the fridge expecting a nice glass of wine and it’s actually the we’s non-alcoholic “Christmas Mulled Berry Punch”, which tastes like a Moroccan’s gusset.The time of year when the rellies turn up, like not very wise men, each bearing their present of a bloody panettone which nobody anywhere will eat.When the awful Lonely This Christmas, by Mud, gets dragged out of its tomb – I’ve hated that song for  years.When good, God-fearing Christian people kick the s**t out of each other in an attempt to secure the last PlayStation, or something, in the sales. Ah well. There are compensations, I suppose.Half a day off work spent with a bottle of Jack Daniel’s and some Mon Cheri liqueurs in my tightly locked office watching a rerun of Millwall beating Arsenal at Highbury in . Can’t top that.It’s been a helluva year – hope you all have a lovely Christmas Day and get all that you wished for. x Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun readers generosity ira john downey
story: It has taken  long years for his ­victims’ determined relatives to get the justice denied to them in the criminal courts by Tony Blair’s Government giving Downey immunity.But it took our readers’ generosity to fund the case after Legal Aid chiefs initially refused.We congratulate the families and hope they now take Downey for every penny he has in damages.And today there will be further good news for those who fought for Britain in the Troubles — as well as their families: a new law at last ending vexatious prosecutions against veterans.For good measure, the Queen’s Speech will announce an end to early release for jailed terrorists too. Excellent.It’s asBritain has been engulfed by a sudden outbreak of common sense.EVEN in a crowded field of terrible options for new Labour leader, Keir Starmer stands out as a stone-cold loser.The man best known for his dismal failures as Director of Public Prosecutions and for talking Labour into its suicidal “people’s vote” strategy.Sir Keir, the multi-millionaire human rights QC now posing as a working-class boy.Only one alternative is LESS likely to win back working-class voters in the North: Emily Thornberry — Lady Nugee, to be formal — another sanctimonious Islington barrister who sneers at working people and marched to reverse their Brexit vote dressed as an EU flag.Labour would be insane to pick either. Especially now we know the election result flattered Corbyn.The boundaries are still skewed in Labour’s favour — and the Brexit Party seems to have gted Corbyn  northern seats by ­preventing certain Tory victories.Labour’s problems run far deeper than they have realised. That’s without picking smug, rich London Remainers as leader.A PLEA to our new Government: go with the evidence. There is no proof sugar taxes work. Don’t even think about more of them.Boris Johnson is clearly no fan of the fizzy drinks levy his predecessors were persuaded to impose. Health Secretary Matt Hancock must not buckle to the same nanny state health lobbyists.Such taxes can only be justiedthey cut obesity. There’s no evidence of that anywhere. Nor will there be, no matter how many milkshakes you add them to. They just make shopping pricier for all.The Tories should use their powerful new mandate to build more sports facilities or boost children’s education about the value of healthy eating and exercise.Not to ramp up taxes with no provable benefit to public health. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we must stop letting violent offenders like ewan ireland out with no restrictions its plain madness
story: Tony Blair’s infamous Antisocial Behaviour Orders were supposed to stop troublemakers causing misery for the public but ended up being broken with impunity and worn as a badge of honour by their recipients.But you may not have heard the letters RUI, standing for Released Under Investigation.If not, you soon will be hearing about them. RUIs are what the Law Society’s head of justice has described as a “major scandal” waiting to erupt.I know Home Secretary Priti Patel will have a lot on her plate as Parliament begins, but this ought to be one of her top priorities.The shocking overuse of RUI came to light on Wednesday, after -year-old thug Ewan Ireland was jailed for le for the murder of solicitor Peter Duncan in a Newcastle shopping centre in August.Peter’s misfortune was to have brushed past Ireland in the doorway of a shop, an act which Ireland took as a slight.He took hold of the screwdriver he had stolen minutes earlier and drove it into Mr Duncan’s heart.It is a tale of mindless, casual violence which has become all too common in modern Britain as the jumped-up egos of young men rage against anyone who gets in their way.But what makes it all the more disturbing is that Ireland’s tendency for extreme violence was well known to police and the courts, yet still he was allowed to walk the streets.While other boys of his age are busy studying for A-levels, Ireland had already amassed a formidable range of criminal qualications.He had  convictions for  dferent offences. He was on conditional discharge for an offence of battery and on bail for a charge of affray for threatening to slash another boy’s Achilles’ tendon.Yet in spite of all this, he had been released under investigation for a robbery.He is not the only violent criminal to have been sent on his way by police. In September last year Alan Martin, of Sunderland, was released by police after his estranged we accused him of raping her.Not only did officers release him, they also ed to him the keys to his we’s house. He promptly ed to the address, attacked her with a hammer and strangled her before taking his own le, too.Astonishingly, Northumbria Police were later cleared by the Independent Office for Police Conduct. No one seems to want to take responsibility. No doubt it will be the same next time, too.Since April , , violent criminals have been released under investigation, Home Office figures reveal.Unlike police bail, no restrictions have been placed on these people. They are not banned from visiting particular places, they have not had to raise a deposit, hand over their passport or report to police at regular intervals. Nor, unlike police bail, is there any time limit on RUI, so police are under no pressure to bring charges quickly.The misuse of RUI is a hangover from Amber Rudd’s time as Home Secretary. It was her Policing and Crime Act  which stopped police putting people on bail for periods of more than  days. True, something needed to be done. The case of former Radio  DJ Paul Gambaccini had inspired the rule change.He had been held on bail for a whole year as police investigated accusations of historic sex offences which turned out to be without foundation.Unable to put criminals on bail for more than  days, police forces took to releasing them under investigation instead.That might be perfectly reasonable in the case of relatively minor crimes which take a long time to investigate, but it is hardly an appropriate way to treat suspected murderers and rapists, especially those with a long history of violent offences.At the very least, people suspected of violent offences — and for which good evidence exists that those offences really did take place — need to be monitored.As for people who have been released on licence while serving sentences for previous convictions, there should be no argument at all — they should be taken back to prison without hesitation.Ministers like to talk tough on crime, especially around election time, but behind the scenes they get caught in the stranglehold of the liberal establishment.Punishments get weakened, prisoners get released early.Disgracefully, former Home Secretary Jack Straw described the sentencing system as the “benign deception of the public”, who, unaware of the soft reality, assume that criminals are being properly punished.But there is nothing benign about serial offenders being freed to rape and murder when police and the courts know full well their records.During the election campaign, Boris Johnson finally called an end to the deception.Braving an onslaught from the nation’s liberal consciences, he announced that prisoners will no longer be eligible for automatic early release — something which allowed the London Bridge killer Usman Khan to embark on his murderous spree.But the Johnson Government should not end there.It needs to stop the police releasing violent offenders back into the community without any restrictions on their movements nor any requirement ever to report to a police station.Liberals like to say that we can’t solve crime just by jailing people. On the contrary, had Ewan Ireland been kept out of circulation after his first offence it would alone have meant  fewer crimes in Newcastle over the past four years.It is hard enough to catch criminals.But to release those we do catch, giving them the freedom to embark on long crime sprees, is plain madness.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: clive lewis labour leadership race
story: But party moderates are delighted at the news as they think it will split the hard-left vote and allow them to take control.Mr Lewis, one of John McDonnell’s deputies in the shadow treasury team, has been asking trade unionsthey will back his leadership bid.Setting out his stall, Mr Lewis toldMr Corbyn’s first vow as leader “was not fulfilled”.He added: “The party was never democratised on the scale that members were led to expect.“They were never empowered to campaign, select candidates or determine policy on the scale that was required.”The move would pit Mr Lewis against felllow leftwinger Rebecca Long-Bailey, who is one of the favourites for the leadership.She told LBC: “The kids when they got seasick would go into the ladies loos, and I went in one day and every sink was full of sick.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 6 hangover cures christmas
story: Thats a lot of sore heads over the course of a week.And while theres no instant miracle cure just yet, there are few things you can do to alleviate those awful hangover symptoms.The key is to focus on replacing the essential vitamins and minerals your entire day drinking wiped out in a flash.But first, its worth understanding exactly what a hangover is - aside from a sign you had a little too much the night before.Nutritionist Amanda Hamilton explains that its a whole series of things that combine to drain our bodies of all the goodness they need.A hangover is a combination of toxin overload coupled with dehydration and vitamin depletion, caused by that harmless one too many, she told The Sun.All alcohol contains toxins and, in fact, the whole experience of getting intoxicated is simply giving your body so many toxins that it cant process them quickly enough.So, how do we get rid of that dreadful feeling Here are just some of the ways you can give your hangover a kicking...It may seem a little obvious, but try and stay hydrated throughout the day, making sure you get the daily two to three litres.Another trick that can be really helpful is to have a large glass of water before you start drinking.Minerals are easily lost in sweat and urine - soyoure going to be doing a lot of dancing or constantly nipping to the loo then its good to give yourself a head start on the hydration stations.Amanda said: Sip throughout the day, aiming for approximately two litres each day, but remember you’ll get some of this from food.Keep urine straw coloured as the yardstick of being At two, he could solve -piece jigsaw puzzles. By five he could recall the size, population and flag of every country on Earth.And by  he’d become a chess grandmaster. You’d imagine, then, that with such a mind he could do anything with his le. Unwrap the secrets of cold fusion.Conquer the problems of faster-than-light travel. Work out how you can open the wrapping of a Gillette razor using only your hands. But no.Instead, Magnus turned his attention to fantasy football, where, inevitably, he’s thrashed seven million other players to become the best in the world.As I write, he’s about to beat the all-time record of  undefeated games. title: perfect pint head scientists
story: Experts used a nuclear reactor to fire neutrons at fluids to assess their foaming qualities.It had previously been possible only to predict such a reaction in samples that had a single ingredient.But the latest method allows experts to tell which recipes will produce the most stable foams.The results from the University of Manchester research showed that even slight dferences in the barley, hops, water and yeast used in beer can make a big dference.Study leader Dr Richard Campbell said: “Scientists have been trying for years to solve this problem. Our discovery could help brewers develop a head on beer that lasts until the last sip or a barista create a foamier coffee.“It will be nice to be able to take your time over your pint and still have a nice head left at the end. Nobody wants a flat pint.”Dr Catherine Tonry, from Campaign for Real Ale, said: “The head forms an important part of a pint, increasing mouth-feel and helping flavour.“But we would be wary of attempts to introduce additives that may affect the quality of the head.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit underway massive majority
story: Who could have imagined this six months ago  Several times in the last torturous three years The Sun almost gave up hope. But not quite.Even we, though, didn’t dare to dream that a proper Brexit — no customs union, no single market, fully taking back control — would pass by a thumping margin under a Boris Johnson Government beginning five years in power.The Remainer wreckers are gone. Yet, incredibly, Brexit was STILL opposed by the twitching corpse of the Labour Party in a last, spiteful two-fingered gesture to its former voters.What don’t these MPs get  They bet the house on a “people’s vote” and lost. And yet they still witter on about second referendums, customs unions or otherwise tying ourselves to the EU.One voice seemed to speak sense. “We recognise the clear message from the public,” said Jeremy Corbyn. “We have to respect that and move on.”Then, ridiculously, he led his rabble through the lobby to vote against Brexit one last time.A historic day, with Labour yet again on the wrong side of it. And for Corbyn, a dismal end to his inglorious week of sullen silence and door-slamming petulance.WE’RE confused.One minute Corbyn takes responsibility for his defeat. The next he blames hostility from “billionaire Press barons”.He cannot grasp a simple reality about The Sun. If we fear a wannabe Government will wreck the economy and destroy our readers’ jobs, we oppose it.But the Left think anyone not devoted to socialist purity must have corrupt motives. And for these zealots the answer is an even more left-wing leader. Maybe contender Clive Lewis, who makes Corbyn look like Norman Tebbit.Unless they grow out of this, they will spend their lives in impotent opposition.IT is high time to end voter fraud, using compulsory photo ID. We are delighted the Tories aim to do it.The Left always protests it is so rare it is not worth the fuss. Whatever could they be worried about  Surely not that the poorest will be deprived of their vote, since photo IDs will be free. What other motive could they have There is a wealth of first-hand or anecdotal evidence of people voting multiple times in dferent constituencies, stealing someone ’s vote, voting by post AND in person and so on.Conviction rates are low only because the system is so wide open it is hard to spot and catch offenders. But this is a serious crime meriting jail every time.And when so many routine tasks now require ID, one as vital to our democracy as casting your ballot certainly should.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris delivered brexit rest done
story: Earlier today, the new House of Commons voted for his deal and the UK will leave on ­January .But this sums up the ­remarkable position that this Government is in. It will have done the main thing that it was put in power to do within two months of taking office.The danger for the Tories is that their new electoral ­coalition was held together by a desire to Get Brexit Done and fear of Jeremy Corbyn, and both of those issues will soon be resolved.As the party’s campaign director, Isaac Levido, pointed out to Tory MPs on Wednesday afternoon, Brexit and Corbyn won this election for the Tories and both of them will be gone by the time of the next ­election, so the Tories have to deliver for their new voters or risk defeat.No  is acutely ­conscious of this risk. They know they need a new glue for their coalition — and fast.At Political Cabinet on Tuesday morning, this point was rammed home to ministers by both the PM and Levido.Levido, a clear-sighted Australian, warned the assembled secretaries of state that the Tories have “not won the domestic policy fight” yet.He stressed that this election had been about Getting Brexit Done more than any other issue.Tory support among Leave voters went from  per cent in  to  per cent, and that was key to the victory.Ministers were told that the party’s polling showed the positive things voters associated with the Tories were about sorting Brexit, while the negative things about Labour were to do with Corbyn or Brexit.Levido was clear that voters were backing the Tories to finish Brexit — not because they had suddenly become Conservatives. Another danger for the Tories is that Labour’s fundamental brand is nowhere near as damaged as many at Westminster think.With Corbyn gone and Brexit removed as an issue, the party may well be able to bounce back much faster than expected.Levido pointed out that the Tories’ own polling of  marginal seats had seen the gap between the two parties narrow to just four points in the aftermath of the manestos, as Labour briefly succeeded in turning the conversation away from Brexit.Boris Johnson and the Tory campaign pushed Brexit back to the top of the agenda.Levido was clear that for this reason the election could not be seen as a categorical rejection of Labour’s policies. The challenge for the Tories is to move fast to deliver change, so that people do not feel tempted to go back to Labour again.Do this right and, over the next decade, Darlington, West Bromwich and Wrexham will become Tory heartlands. Get it wrong and these places will turn red once again.Boris told cabinet ministers that voters needed to see and feel change in their local AE and on their roads and high streets.He said there needed to be a clear reduction in homelessness and voters must know that they and their family have a better chance of owning a home. This election made the Tories a national party again.Now they must show these new voters that their cares are Conservative concerns — and that the party knows how to fix the problems. They must deliver for the whole nation.WHERE is the geographical centre of the new Tory party  Well, before the election it was Buckinghamshire.Now it is South Yorkshire, where the Tories hold three seats – Rother Valley, Don Valley and Penistone And Stocksbridge.James Cleverly, the ebullient Tory chairman, has relished telling colleagues this fact. I understand that to reflect this new reality, the Tories are planning to move a large chunk of their party headquarters up north.The thinking is that by getting a chunk of the party operation out of London and into the North, it will make the party less London-centric and more attuned to the concerns of the rest of the country.BORIS JOHNSON is determined that next year must not be as dominated by Brexit as this year has been. He told Cabinet this week that once the UK leaves the EU on January , they should stop talking about Brexit.The PM argued that while the EU would try to create new clf edges and fresh moments of drama, the Government should resist being drawn into this dynamic.He argued that ministers should instead approach it as a normal trade negotiation rather than as some epoch-defining event.I am told that as part of the Government’s effort to de-dramatise things, they intend to resist going to Brussels for every negotiation – something which only adds to the tension and drama.I understand they want negotiations on both sides of the Channel rather than the UK always looking like a supplicant in heading to Europe to be told what it can and cannot have.As part of the effort to lower the profile of these trade talks, I am informed that David Frost – Boris’s understated but effective EU sherpa – will carry on conducting the negotiations.Frost, who is trusted totally by the PM and his inner circle, secured the changes to the withdrawal agreement that made it acceptable to Tory MPs. Having Frost conduct the negotiations rather than a cabinet minister will make them less likely to dominate the news.But there is no getting away from the importance of these talks to the UK. The deal will be the first trade deal the nation has done in -odd years and will be hugely important in determining the future economic direction of this country.The Tories calculate that, for his part, Sir Keir Starmer, the strongest Shadow Cabinet advocate of a second referendum, would deepen Labour’s problem in Leave-voting seats.The only candidate currently causing some concern is Jess Phillips – regarded as the high-risk, high-reward option for Labour.But given her low standing with the Corbyn-backing membership, she is not currently looking like a top- tier candidate.WHEN two or three ministers are gathered together, they start to nervously whisper about the February reshuffle.It is expected that this reshuffle will be big and coincide with the changes to Whitehall that Boris Johnson is keen to introduce. He wants to create some new departments, merge others and even shutter some.Boris’s old allies, though, are warning against a shake-up that sees too many of them replaced.One confidant of this group tells me Boris’s new support base in the party is “a mile wide and an inch deep” and that he needs to keep close those who have been loyal to him through thick and thin.One person who is certain to be rewarded in the reshuffle is Brandon Lewis, the Security Minister.Johnson’s team were impressed by his work during the campaign and want to use him more in the media.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queen has endured one of the toughest years of her long reign, according to royal experts. The monarch once famously dubbed  her aposAnnus horribilisapos and  has been something of a re-run for the -year-old. Over the past  months, her husband Prince Philip had a police warning for his involvement in a car crash, her grandsons Princes William and Harry publicly fell out and her second son Prince Andrew got ever more entangled in his links to paedophile US financier Jeffrey Epstein. And now Philipaposs health has again come into question, after he was admitted to hospital on Friday aposfor a few daysapos.Of the year as a whole, royal biographer Penny Junor said: This is as bad as it gets for her. Twenty seven years ago the Queen used a speech at the Guildhall to describe her year as an annus horribilis. The year was wrecked by the collapse of three of her childrenaposs marriages - including Prince Charlesapos to Princess Diana - and the fire that severely damaged her Windsor Castle home. Ms Junor said: She obviously wonapost use that phrase again, but I would suspect in some ways thishas been even worse. Prince Philip car crash near Sandringham In January, Elizabethaposs -year-old husband Prince Philip was involved in a car accident near the familyaposs Sandringham estate. The Duke, , was miraculously unharmed other than a few bumps and scrapes. However he had to give up his driving licence after police gave him a warning for driving without wearing a seat belt.  Prince Andrewaposs links with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein The decision by Prince Andrew to take part in an interview with BBC Newsnight about his friendship with convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein backfired spectacularly. Days after the grilling in Buckingham Palace the Duke of York was sidelined from his royal role with speculation he may never do public engagements again. The father-of-two was judged to have badly handled the questions by Emily Maitlis and even refused to say his friendship with Epstein, who died this year awaiting trial for further child sex trafficking charges, was a mistake.  The Duke has vehemently denied allegations he had sex with teenager Virginia Roberts but the backlash from the interview was swt and Prince Charles, who was in New Zealand at the time, is tipped to have had a hand in his ousting from a public role. Criticism of Meghan and Harry The Queenaposs grandson Prince Harry, rumoured to be her favourite, and his we Meghan have taken strong action against the press. The couple were criticised for renovating their Frogmore Cottage home using taxpayer money and also using a private jet while speaking out on climate change.  A documentary that was supposed to highlight their work on their South Africa tour instead focused on perceived negative media coverage of the couple and particularly of Meghan, who gave birth to her first son Archie in May. Meghan spoke on the documentary about the intense toll the unfair media coverage has taken on her well-being. Harry also spoke about his mental health struggles. I thought I was out of the woods and then suddenly it all came back, and then suddenly I realized no, this is something that I have to manage, Harry said.  Part of this job, and part of any job like everybody, means putting on a brave face and turning a cheek to a lot of the stuff. But again, for me and for my we, of course there’s a lot of stuff that hurts, especially when the majority of it is untrue. Rumours of a rt between brothers Harry and William Gossip from royal insiders continued to suggest throughout  that a rt had developed between Prince William and his brother Prince Harry. In that same documentary on the Sussexaposs tour of South Africa Harry was asked directly about them and didnapost deny it out of hand.  Part of this role and part of this job and this family, being under the pressure that it’s under — inevitably, you know, stuff happens. But look, we’re brothers, we’ll always be brothers, he said. We’re certainly on dferent paths at the moment, but I’ll always be there for him and as I know he’ll always be there for me. We donapost see each other as much as we used to because we’re so busy, but, you know, I love him dearly and the majority of the stuff is probably — well the majority of the stuff is created out of nothing. As brothers, you know, you have good days, you have bad days. Queen dragged into political row The Queen herself was embroiled in political wrangling over Britainaposs exit from the European Union, with her suspension of parliament in September at the behest of Prime Minister Boris Johnson ruled unlawful by the countryaposs top court. The royal family always go to great s to keep themselves away from the political arena but the Queen, unwittingly, played a part in the autumn Brexit fiasco with the Supreme Court judging that she was lied to about the reasons for prorogation.  Royal historian Robert Lacey said Septemberaposs Supreme Court ruling was more signicant than Prince Andrewaposs interview with it possibly heralding the end of the monarchyaposs few remaining prerogative powers and posing questions about its future constitutional role. It could reduce the monarch to an essentially ceremonial and charitable role, he said. The new involvement of the Supreme Court doesnapost question the existence of the monarchy - yet. Butcertain decisions and prerogatives are going to be controlled or taken away, then what has the prime minister got to go to speak to the queen about each week  Queen rises above scandals Most people will look upon  as not a particularly good year for the institution but the Queen came out pretty well, said Dickie Arbiter, Elizabethaposs press secretary from  to . The monarchy has evolved over , years. It has had all sorts of circumstances running against it, but it has survived. It survived , it survived the abdication of, it survived .  Some have gone as far as saying the family could eventually emerge even stronger - and that this yearaposs traumas could lay the foundations of a new slimmed-down monarchy, a long-term aim of future king Prince Charles. Royal historian Robert Lacey said: Itaposs a tragedy in a way, but it is a plus to see Charles playing a positive role in events. After  years, Charles is finally getting his way. One of those whose support they can count on is the Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, spiritual leader of the worldaposs  million Anglicans.

story: NewsConman photographer who lured women into fake porn shoots found guilty of rapePaul Brown, who operated under the  name of Paul Smart, set up a bogus modelling agency which he used to manipulate his victims who he raped at his Okehampton studioShareByTed Davenport:,  DEC NewsConvicted rapist Paul Brown - who operated under the  name Paul Smart" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Paul Brown deceived the women into believing they could be glamour or adult starsthey stripped off or joined him in casting couch sex sessions. He set up a bogus modelling agency which he pretended had nothing to do with him and which he actually controlled and used to manipulate the victims. The models thought the agency was genuine and could find them work but onlythey went for apostest shootsapos at his studio in Okehampton, where he operated under the  name of Paul D Smart. Brown invented two fictional women, who supposedly ran the Models South West agency. Brown, through the agency contacted many of the victims of Facebook, told them they had the potential to be models, and inviting them to the studio.  Once they were there, he persuaded some to have sex with him on camera and others to strip for what he called aposartistic nudeapos sessions where he in fact focussed his camera on their private parts. The rape victims were told they could earn large amounts by posing for a type of pornography called POV or point of view, in which the participants film themselves having sex. They all thought the material would be sent to the agency Model South West, which would find them work. In reality, the agency was a sham and Brown kept the images for his own sexual gratication. Some of the models who had sex with him were lured back to his studio on the Fatherford Farm trading estate in Okehampton by messages from the modelling agency saying the scenes had to be re-shot. One model who was reluctant to strip naked heard Brown call Model South West and pretend to have a conversation with the agency about how she was ideal for nude work. The models came from all over Devon and were of all ages and sizes, ranging from their late teens to their s, Many were vulnerable and insecure about their bodies and were fooled by Brownaposs smooth talking and flattery. None of them ever received any offers of work and none of them received any of the money which he promised would follow. Brown kept a record of his sexual conquests in a aposblack bookapos which recorded details of some of the rape victims. The book contained the names, ages, physical details of Brownaposs partners and included a mark out of ten for their performance. The book even included his own we, who scored nine out of ten. The whole set up with the agency was a device to con women into satisfying his sexual appetite, which was described as sleazy and sordid by the prosecution. Brown joked with police in one interview that he was not Harvey Weinstein but employed a classic casting couch technique of offering fame and fortune in exchange for sex. The couch actually came from Ikea. He set himself up as a photographer despite having little formal training and a background as an IT adviser, at one stage working for the NHS in Exeter. Brown committed the offences while running his studio at the Fatherford Farm trading estate in Okehampton between  and . The police were first alerted in  by one of the rape victims who went to a genuine modelling shoot with a professional photographer a few days afterwards.  She realised that what Brown had done amounted to a sexual assault and went to the police, who arrested him and seized the black book. He carried on in exactly the same way while he was being investigated by police and went on to rape another two women. Brown was found guilty of  out of  charges including  rapes against six dferent women. He was also found guilty of voyeurism against five other women. He pleaded guilty to one count of voyeurism, which involved him installing a hidden camera at his home to spy on a young female visitor in the bathroom. He was cleared of four counts of sexual assault, which alleged that he touched models while rubbing oil onto their bodies during shoots. Brown, aged , of Okehampton, denied a total of  rapes against seven women, four of sexual assault against four women, and six of voyeurism against six women. He said all the women consented to what he did, in many cases in advance and in writing. He was found guilty of  rapes and five counts of voyeurism and remanded in custody by Judge David Evans, who adjourned sentence until February. He put Brown on the sex offenders register and ordered the probation service to prepare a report of whether Brown is a dangerous offender. He told him:You have been convicted of many of these serious offences and in due course you will be sentenced to a signicant time in custody. The appropriate time will only be decided in the light of the relevant material.

And  seems to be no dferent with revellers in Newcastle, Leeds, Cardf and Manchester enjoying a night on the tiles before Christmas next week. This year Sheffield city centre sergeant Jon Simpson warned people not to spend their festive season behind bars due to their antics on what is also referred to as aposBlack Eye Fridayapos. He said: Make sure youaposve got a plan for getting home and donapost put yourself in a position where you make yourself vulnerable and potentially end up a victim of crime. You also donapost want to commit crime and end up in a police cell over the Christmas period.In party-mad Newcastle one woman in a short snake-skin mini-skirt decided to perform a handstand against a tree and the same woman, in the party spirit, was also pictured on a manaposs shoulders mimicking flying through the air. The woman appeared to be keen to get everyone in the festive mood, at one stage dancing in the streets with a man in a pink cowboy hat on her shoulders. A game effort by another woman enjoying a night out appeared to end in failure. But not all the action on Tyneside was in the party spirit with two young men appearing to square up to one another in the street, with one grabbing the other by the throat as friends urge them to calm down. One group of male revellers were all wearing the iconic Ash Ketchum Pokemon hat - but one of their number was wearing an inflatable Pikachu suit. Also in the Welsh capital one man was wrestled to the ground by door staff outside Popworld on St Maryaposs Street. The cold winter air was not enough to dissuade one male reveller from dancing topless to a saxophone busker, also on St Maryaposs Street which is one of the busiest areas for nightle in the city. In Manchester one man dressed in an inflatable turkey had a clash with a friend before resting against a wall.  Likewise in Leeds there was fancy dress on Friday, albeit with more of a festive theme. But where in the city centre two men were pictured getting into a scrap on the road before a police officer intervened. Neither is thought to have been seriously hurt.  In a quieter scene one man, in fancy dress to look like Santa was carrying him on his shoulders, sat at a bus station in Leeds, scrolling through his phone and supping from a hip flask. Superintendent Chris Hill, who leads on Policing in the Night Time Economy at Greater Manchester Police, said Mancunians said before Fridayaposs natics that revellers will see more officers around on Mad Friday. We always plan ahead for Christmas and New Year, working alongside other emergency services and partners to ensure we have a well-rounded plan in place, he said.  We expect to welcome large numbers of persons over these periods. The Christmas Markets, planned events at the numerous sporting and music arenas, office Christmas parties and fireworks on NYE all add extra footfall to the already busy City centre. Sean Joyce, Head of Regulatory and Criminal Justice at Stephensons Solicitors LLP, called Mad Friday one of the most notorious drinking days of the year.  Itaposs the culmination of the working year and a time when every workplace up and down the country wants to let their hair down and celebrate the Christmas break, he said. However, a night of drinking can cause alcohol fuelled problems and some workers can become easily riled and aggressive, which can lead to arguments with colleagues or strangers.

Police and Asda are investigating after Joanne Aiken claims there were several sharp pins in the bunch of bananas.Asda say they have no idea how this could have happened - but they are taking it extremely seriously, reports Edinburgh Live . Joanne, of Falkirk, posted on Facebook : Just to make everyone aware when buying bananas from Asda, Grangemouth. Please check them.These were found in each of ours. One last night and today my wee boy bit into one and found another. Please be carefulyou or your wee ones eat bananas. Totally shocking, she added. She said that she later found more needles after inspecting the rest of the bananas from the same bunch. Police are working alongside the supermarket to investigate the incident. After they were made aware of the grim discovery, staff at the store recalled the bananas on the shop floor to check for more foreign objects but say they found nothing. title: mum who fled home six
story: NewsMum who fled home with six kids and just £ now facing a Christmas crisisMaryams six children are suffering from poor living conditions in cramped BB which is impacting school performance and health as they wait for suitable accommodationShareCommentsByJane HaynesLila Randall:,  DEC NewsMum and her six kids among many families in housing crisis " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother who fled her family home with her six children and only £ in her pocket is stuck in a crisis before Christmas. The woman - given the pseudonym Maryam - lives in cramped temporary accommodation after escaping months of trauma and upset at home.The family of seven are awaiting a suitable place to rent but Birmingham City Council has housed the family in a BB only meant for short-stays, Birmingham Live reports. The grizzly situation for this family of seven is not isolated.  They are among a staggering  kids spending the run-up to Christmas in a BB or hotel room in the city. Most will still be there on Christmas Day, and the prospect of a turkey dinner and an excess of treats is remote and presents are likely to be in short supply. When Maryam’s children were asked what they wanted for Christmas their answer was humbling. Her youngest child, a three year old, said he wanted “yoghurt and some colours”. Meanwhile, his -year-old brother wants stationary for school. He said: “I’d like a book to help me with my SATS - and I wish for Airpods.  Maryam has endured a traumatic seven weeks after fleeing the family home in October. The family has since lived in a BB, with mum trying to keep a semblance of normal le going for the kids, aged three to . Thankfully, the situation facing this family is about to improve, after a last minute intervention from Birmingham City Council. They could be out of the BB by Monday afternoon. A brief message from the council read: A move to more suitable self-contained accommodation has been arranged for next Monday .  But for  other families, including  kids, Christmas Day will be spent in a Birmingham BB room. Most of them will have been there for several weeks at a time, living in a space suitable for short stays, not miserable months. It is a dark and stark sign of a city in the grip of the national housing crisis, with a drastic shortage of council homes and affordable private properties for rent. Birmingham City Council is trying to stem the tide of need but itaposs a struggle, and the number of kids caught up in the crisis just keeps going up. Maryam, , left the family home in a hurry in the autumn with her six children, aged three to . It was the culmination of months of trauma and upset, and she sought support from Birmingham City Council, Womenaposs Aid and her childrenaposs schools.  I told the council what had been happening, and spoke to Womenaposs Aid and the police for help, she said. The council first said they could not do anything to help with a house because we are a big family, so they could not give us suitable accommodation, they had nothing for us. She spent a couple of nights with a friend - her family of seven, and her friendaposs family of ten, crammed into a small house. The family were then housed in a Travelodge and, later, sent to the BB where they have been living since October . Thereaposs nowhere for the kids to play, no garden to run around in, no desk for homework, no table to eat at and no privacy.  The children have broken up from school for the holidays, and Maryam said she was uncertain how often she would be able to feed them. They usually have breakfast and lunch at school, and in the evenings they mostly rely on fast, hot food from cheap takeaways or supermarkets, she said. The little nine year old is very underweight - a letter from a health visitor, expressing concern at how desperate the familyaposs situation is and the impact on their health, is among a pile of supporting documents pressing the city council to move the family out of the BB. The bundle also includes a letter from the familyaposs GP, which says Maryam has type  diabetes, chronic back pain and anxiety and that one of the children is on nutritional supplements to boost her weight.  Mum Maryam used to work in a nursery school but has had to stop work since becoming homeless and ending up in the BB. She has managed to keep the family car on the road - without it, thereaposs no chance the children would be able to continue at the schools they love. But the running costs are an extra strain. Mum Maryam says one of her ladaposs school performance has dropped since the turmoil of the family breakup: His reading is not good but he is very bright, but there is nowhere quiet for him or any of the children to study or think. It is hard for him.  Saidul Haque Saeed, lead organiser for Citizens UK in Birmingham, and his organisation has been supporting Maryam since her plight came to their attention, and they have been advocating on her behalf for an urgent move into a permanent home. We are seeing so many cases like this, all over Birmingham. It is a shocking state of affairs, a real scandal, driven by a lack of social housing and a lack of affordable private rented accommodation. The system is broken in the city. He has also drawn together a multi-cultural, multi-faith group of campaigners who have now started to lobby the city council, the West Midlands Combined Authority and the Government on social housing provision. There are simply too few places in the city for families in dficulty to find security and peace, he says.  In early , the number of households - including families - sent to BBs was close to . Many were being sent out of the city, tearing them away from any support networks and schools. The cityaposs Cabinet member responsible for homelessness, Coun Sharon Thompson, took over the portfolio in May  and pledged to bring that number down drastically. She recognises that a BB room is no place for a family and has pledged to bring the number down to zero. By this time last year that figure had nearly halved, with  households of all sizes living in BBs, including  families and  children. But in the past year progress has stalled, despite a series of new measures.  At the start of this week, the number of affected families has reduced slightly to  - but the number of children caught up in the crisis has rocketed to . Many of the families affected are large, and the current housing stock is just not able to cope. The stubbornly static number of affected families comes despite concerted efforts all year by the council to deal with demand. But no sooner is one family helped than more arrive seeking support. The council is currently seeing  new families every month - enough to fill four tower blocks. The Homelessness Reduction Act, introduced earlier this year, has made it easier for people to get help and is designed to ensure people are supported earlier, with a focus on preventing them becoming homeless in the first place.  But itaposs a seemingly unmanageable tsunami of need. A Birmingham City Council spokesperson said: “Bed and breakfast accommodation is emergency accommodation only and used as a last resort. It is a safety net that’s in place to protect the most vulnerable homeless households and we recognise this is type of accommodation is only suitable short term. “Our priority is to prevent people from becoming homeless in the first place and as such we have been working with partners in the public and third sectors to ensure that we identy and reach people who are at risk of homelessness at a much earlier stage and before they come to us as statutory homeless.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe hero who tackled terrorist Usman Khan has described how he battled with the attacker while armed with a narwhal tusk.Talking for the first time, Darryn Frost said he is still recovering from the “traumatic events” of that day on London Bridge.The -year-old civil servant took the sea creatureaposs appendage and used it to keep murderous Khan at bay.Until now Darrynaposs identity was a mystery and he says he still feels a deep hurt at not being able to save the jihadist’s two victims. Darryn was among brave members of the public who fought convicted terrorist Khan as he lunged at people with knives. Footage from November  shows Darryn wielding the tusk on London Bridge. He is seen pinning Khan to the ground and being pulled away by an armed police officer before the fiend – who was wearing a fake suicide vest – is shot dead. Tragically, by the time he was stopped he had killed Jack Merritt, , and Saskia Jones, . Darryn was at the same prisoner rehabilitation event in Fishmongers’ Hall at London Bridge, Central London, as Khan when the maniac launched his attack. Recalling how the horror unfolded, he said: “When we heard the noise from the floor below, a few of us rushed to the scene. I took a narwhal tusk from the wall and used it to defend myself and others from the attacker. Another man was holding him at bay with a wooden chair. “I ran down the stairs, stood next to the man with the chair, and the two of us confronted the attacker.“He had knives in both hands and, upon seeing me with the narwhal tusk, indicated he had an explosive device around hiswaist.The man next to me threw his chair at the attacker, who then started running towards him.”  Darryn, , passed the tusk to the man before racing to grab another one. When he ed, he saw the first tusk “shattered across the floor” and people fleeing. He said: “Along with others, I pursued the attacker, tusk in hand, on to the bridge. We called out to warn the public and managed to restrain him to the ground.” One of the heroes Darryn fought with was reformed ex-prisoner John Crilly, who sprayed Khan with a fire extinguisher after seeing his suicide vest.  The -year-old helped to push Khan back from ­Fishmongers’ Hall and told the Mirror days after the drama: “I keep spraying him, he can’t see and that gives the whale guy a chance to give him a poke.” Darryn, a South African who has lived in London for  years, said he had omitted “many details” in his account, “out of respect for the victims and their families” and due to the ongoing probe and inquests. But he said he wanted to speak out to help tackle terrorism and raise cash for the families Khan has devastated. And he added: I feel we all have a duty to ­challenge the spread of fear, hatred or intolerance within our communities. I hope the part I played in these terrible events can be used for good. Offering his condolences to Jack and Saskia’s loved ones, he said: “I am convinced they represent all that is good in the world and I will always feel the deep hurt of not being able to save them.”  Darryn also praised the people Khan wounded for being “so brave” – saying some refused treatment until others who were more seriously hurt were tended to first. He added: “That consideration and kindness filled me with hope on that dark day. And Darryn said he was “eternally grateful” to the people who helped, adding: “Not only do I want to thank those who confronted the attacker but also those who put themselves in danger to tend to the injured, relying on us to protect them while they cared for others.”Darryn, who works in the Ministry of Justice communications department, is now urging people to “challenge hate and spread kindness” by backing his peace project, Extinguish Hate. He is also asking people to donate to fundraising pages for the victims, at saskia-jones.muchloved and Celebration Of The Le Of Jack Merritt on GoFundMe. Khan, of Stafford, was arrested in December  and jailed in  for terror offences. He did two rehabilitation courses before his release in December .
